sentences.sentence: China's militarization of islets in the South China Sea, egregious human rights abuses in Xinjiang, incursions into the Taiwan Strait, authoritarian encroachment in Hong Kong, military buildup on its border with India and relentless cyberattacks on its neighbours are but a few of the urgent challenges facing the rules-based international order in the Indo-Pacific.Meeting these challenges requires steadfast co-operation.

And, though it's been a long time coming, that appears to be precisely what global leaders are starting to do.Take the recent meeting between U.S. President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Suga Yoshihide.

The two leaders agreed to a new global partnership to tackle the host of challenges posed by China, including the need for a peaceful resolution to cross-Strait issues, given China's recent aggression toward Taiwan.

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken also expressed his concerns about the Chinese government's increased aggression and reaffirmed America's strong support for Taiwan.It is heartening to see that two of the most important players on the global stage are taking these challenges seriously.
And this comes amidst a significant strategic realignment.

Just recently, the bipartisan Taiwan International Solidarity Act was introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives, which is aimed at countering efforts to exclude Taiwan from international organizations.

Further legislation to protect democracy and human rights by stopping investments that benefit aggressors and human rights abusers is also being considered in the United States.There is a growing realization among major world powers that they need to stand up for countries like Taiwan.

The recent communique following the G7 foreign ministers' meeting in London expressly supported Taiwan's participation in World Health Organization forums and the World Health Assembly, and underscored the importance of peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.Other countries, such as the Czech Republic, have recently sent high-level delegations to Taiwan, and much of the international community - Canada included - have expressed heartfelt support for Taiwan's meaningful inclusion in international organizations.

The recent decision by the Halifax International Security Forum to award the John McCain Prize for Leadership in Public Service to Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen, for example, was well received internationally.These actions indicate that momentum is building within the international community for a new, stronger re-alignment toward a more principled form of multilateral co-operation.

This emerging informal coalition is seeing the world's democracies combine their efforts to ensure that aggressive and revisionist actors are constrained in their abilities to bully other states.For this effort to succeed, we must endeavour to expand the co-operation between democratic countries with shared values.
It is our hope that Taiwan will be seen as an indispensable partner at the vanguard of democracy, holding the torch high for the values we share in an otherwise challenging corner of the world.

This is why it is so important that countries like Canada make their support for Taiwan explicit.Taiwan is a ready and willing economic partner that's eager to join, and positively contribute to, multilateral trade efforts such as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership.

Economic co-operation will strengthen the global economic recovery and bolster our collective ability to resist attempts at economic coercion.Taiwan's handling of COVID-19 and its dedication to addressing challenges like climate change make it an ideal partner for international institutions.

Though pressure from China precludes Taiwanese involvement for the time being, a concerted effort on the part of the free and democratic world can reverse this trend.Ultimately, while Taiwan stands ready and able to deter any and all threats to its citizens, the most effective way to prevent authoritarian overreach from threatening the rules-based international order is for democratic countries to speak out and respond to those threats, consistently and without hesitation.

With a unified and principled call to action, we can make clear to the world's authoritarian states that revisionism will not succeed, and that democracy will neither be shaken nor undermined.Amidst the challenges facing the international community, the world's democracies are now finding that unified and clarion voices will deter authoritarian ambition.
We ask that Taiwan be allowed to join the chorus.National PostPeter MacKay is a former minister of foreign affairs, national defence, justice and attorney general of Canada.

Winston Wen-yi Chen is the representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada.Chen Shih-chung: Taiwan deserves a seat at the WHO(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/chen-shih-chung-taiwan-deserves-a-seat-at-the-who)Jesse Kline: Taiwan's unstable, but necessary, status quo(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/jesse-kline-taiwans-unstable-but-necessary-status-quo) !

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

And, though it's been a long time coming, that appears to be precisely what global leaders are starting to do.Take the recent meeting between U.S. President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Suga Yoshihide. The two leaders agreed to a new global partnership to tackle the host of challenges posed by China, including the need for a peaceful resolution to cross-Strait issues, given China's recent aggression toward Taiwan. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken also expressed his concerns about the Chinese government's increased aggression and reaffirmed America's strong support for Taiwan.It is heartening to see that two of the most important players on the global stage are taking these challenges seriously. We ask that Taiwan be allowed to join the chorus.National PostPeter MacKay is a former minister of foreign affairs, national defence, justice and attorney general of Canada.
